commentBody: Re the Thursday mini… I’ve never heard of garlic knots.

As Moronie from "Johnny Dangerously" once said, "fargin ice holes".

Fun puzzle!
No ICE for me, thanks...

Please can someone explain droll?

Good puzzle.

I’m almost at two years of zero alcohol.  So, this one became a tough one because I was thinking the answers could have been “with a branch”, a zest, on ice, straight up. 

I totally blanked on neat. 

11/8/23

Very n.  

I had a couple wrong fills tripping me up -- vanish for 37A and jusT for 1A (I had ___T and don't know Van Halen) -- but it ended up ok. Got NEAT on first pass, so when I got BENTO with crosses, the theme clicked. 

I do not personally get FOMO for parties -- which may be why I don't go to many! I'll go out for a good concert (usually symphony), otherwise I prefer quiet evenings at home with my dog and cat and a good book.
Still Dre 2002??

A nicely themed puzzle with lots of theme answers that made real words by omitting ICE, almost as if it had melted away.  I was helped by guessing DRE without any basis, and the fact that a lot of the general knowledge clues were in my wheelhouse.  I did spend some time trying to fit in an ICE rebus, but soon saw the non-IOERROR of my ways.

This theme absolutely baffled me. I got neat immediately but could not figure the connection. When I hv whisky I enjoy it neat so the thought of ice did not form for me. I considered SETINSTONE as a reference to those stones people chill to cool their whisky, nope nope nope. They tend to flavor the pour, yuck.

I finished the entire puzzle on crosses and had to read comments to understand. Clever but sadly lost on me.

Reaction to Mr. Aya's puzzle - vote below:

LOVE __
HATE __
NONE ✓*

*N(ICE) ONE

I loved the theme. But 3D initially threw me off since the entry fits the clue, with or without the ICE.
Today's procedure: fill in 22A raiSe, 26D droneS > finish puzzle > correct 22A/26D

Fun and breezy. I love these kinds of themes, and it can’t have been easy to find all these words that you can take ICE out of and still have words (or crossword clues in the case of SLR). And we get two revealers, more or less, and ROCKSOUT is a pretty fun one. I admit I sneaked a peak after the first theme clue I came across at the revealer and got NEAT right away—which gave the theme away once I got BENTO—I might have enjoyed it more if let it simmer a bit. But that’s my problem. The fill was pretty solid.
My only nit/observation is that since Lincoln was one of the first Republicans (apparently he didn’t found it as I had heard) it would be hard to imagine that it was the GOP (Grand OLD Party) when he was leading it. I looked it up, and that’s true; although it apparently started being called the GOP as early as the 1870s when it still was not very old. I’m not going to berate anyone about the clue, it just made me smirk a bit.
NEAT idea all around, and for me a nice relaxing solve after yesterday’s which was a little more taxing.
Beautifully constructed puzzle, with all the themers working as valid fill with and without ice.  Nice!

It’s SET IN STONE she CRAVES no ICE, the drink will still GO COLD. I’ll PASO the ICE as READE the ORACLE READ PALMS OFF HOURS. The PRUDES will HOIST their eyes as the AURORA WEND(s) across the skies, but not near the running EMU who never met the GOTHS. I hope the IT PRO fixed the IO ERROR before the satellite ORBIT(s) away. ETTU IVES now NEEDED A NAP. Ok some was a little tricky but my first attempt at getting most of the puzzle pieces together logically

WiND and RiADE was my natick.

Had gar (Grand Army of the Republic, 37d) for a while, then usa, then finally GOP.  Don’t think GOP was much used when Lincoln lived, nor was gar.  But close enough for a crossword.

I saw the trick at SLR.

Great fun, thanks!

A good  puzzle, spoiled by solving online and filling in rebus  answers for the ice clues  as in many past puzzles ...only to have the system reject the solution.  Frustrating to look for errors that weren't there.

The NYT  needs to be consistent in any puzzle when rebus is needed or allow the rebus as an acceptable solution if it does the job.

A lot of empty grid after the first couple of passes, and it took me a long time to figure out the trick. I got NEAT pretty early but thought I had to use those letters or remove some of those letters or something, especially since 3D worked as-is with the clue (cruel, cruel joke, that one).

In the end, ignorance prevailed since I could only think of one deli device, which cracked the puzzle and opened up several of the other theme clues. 

Ended up just a few seconds under my Thursday average, but certainly thought 'twas going to take longer than that. 

Fun puzzle!
nICE

Noice!  
It’s only missing an inflatable frog somewhere in the grid.

Re: 62A - Marilyn's workplace advice seems curiously dated: 

There may come a time 
When a hard-boiled employer 
Thinks you're awful nice, 
But get that ice or else no dice.

He's your guy 
When stocks are high, 
But beware when they start to descend.

It's then that those louses 
Go back to their spouses. 
Diamonds are a girl's best friend.

Right off the starting block, this puzzle was on fire 🔥 Van Halen’s AIN’T Talkin’ ‘Bout Love performed at the US Festival right before I started high school was epic. https://youtu.be/rzYPpaPf6eg?si=KXc2vJQlGy9NU1L- The theme was on point 👌🏼 Especially given what’s happening in my state in particular. Well done, Kareem, well done.

Don’t need black coffee or to stay up until three. 

This puzzle’s too sweet for me 🎶

Fun puzzle! 

I was confused when I thought I answered everything correctly but didn’t get the star. Turns out my rebuses (eg. S-LICE-R) weren’t accepted by the answer checker. Once I took out the ICE it worked.

Bartending is whiskey business.

(I have mixed feelings about it.)
A timely puzzle.

Captain Sensible would like to remind you that some puzzles are not of this earth . . .

Be a clue, can a mystery clue
Be a word, be a chilly word
It can't be filled, not anyway
It can't be found, no way at all
A solving man, can't sympathize
He can't uphold his rebus laws
Due to form on this Thursday
I got a feeling then I hear this call

Kareem said, NEAT, NEAT, NEAT
He said it would be nice to
NEAT, NEAT, NEAT
It aint pricy at all!
NEAT, NEAT, NEAT
I can't afford no dice roll
NEAT, NEAT, NEAT
Ice got no fill to call
NEAT, NEAT, NEAT

No net if there ain't no law
No blue pill to mess you around
No more dreams of rebus discord
No digital rain to bring you down
You got a crazy, got a thought in your mind
Oracle's mind on when you fall asleep
Feelin' fine in your gold star time
Then these clues upon you creep . . .

NEAT NEAT NEAT
Cheers to Mr. Ayas (or not)

Was a little unsure what was going on when the *d answers fit, but didn't make sense with the clues. My usual pattern is to start at the top and work down, so it took a while to get to the revealer(s), which relieved my uncertainty. Very clever construction, and I appreciate that the theme answers were valid entries on their own, despite not matching the clues without the trick.

I didn't quite have Deb's reaction to 28D, and I did answer it immediately, but it was a fantastic clue/answer set. There are other sites that wave the wand at you (the "Most Magical Place on Earth" for one) if you set off their sensors, and the magnet on my wife's sunglasses case caused a slight delay in our visit to Animal Kingdom this afternoon.

NEAT puzzle, and had me going for a while, thanks, Kareem!
Today I learned “persisting” has the same number of letters as “SET IN STONE”.

Terrific, fun puzzle! And I also prefer things NEAT....  

Or, up with a twist!!

Cheers to a fun puzzle...  and to a much better, neater, tomorrow! 

🍸🌴🍸

My favorite part of this puzzle was the double revealer. NEAT was easy to guess from its clue, but it wasn’t enough to clue me into the gimmick of the puzzle. ROCKS OUT was cleverly clued and helped make the penny drop. 
After that it was smooth sailing…perhaps a bit too smooth for a Thursday. 

Will there be much discussion of the “cheating” question. I’ll be happy to tune it out.

Very neat Puzzle, *To be fair. 

I have to say that after yesterday's Chromebook CLUE in the Mini and today's IOERROR clue, I am beginning to feel that us Windows users are getting no love around here. I/O errors are not just a PC issue and may have nothing to do with disks. 

JUST(ICE) for PC users.
Couldn't get the solve and it was because I had 33a as WiND instead of WEND so yeah, I agree, lookups are fair play.

and now its time for a perfectly serviceable installment of everyones favorite thursday game show:

IS IT OR ISNT IT A REBUS?!

(cue the price is right theme)...
Still DRE is from 1999, not 2022.
Loved the theme and it was such a fun solve. Did anyone else think that 4-down was a lazy clue?

I enjoyed this. I got the properly-Thursday-worthy theme quickly and even though I struggled a bit with the TRIVIA, I solved the puzzle without outside help, and in Wednesday time, too (whereas yesterday's "Wednesday" required Friday/Saturday time). I thought the trick was really cool - the theme entries not being gibberish with ICE taken out was a true testament to the constructor's skill. Cool stuff.
The crossword shouldn't be so obscure that it requires an accompanying article to make it make sense.

Genuine question for the people who tried to input a rebus: Wouldn’t you expect that to break the rest of your solve? It seems to me that the only way this crossword could possibly be solved is by omitting “ICE”, otherwise the crosses (which don’t intersect with ICE or any of its individual letters) would explode.

Another recent example of an anti-rebus.  Instead of having multiple letters in one box you have multiple letters in zero boxes.

This is even more mind-bending than a rebus.

But we can adapt to this anti-pattern.  We need to adjust our frequencies, much like the Borg, to combat this threat.

Sometimes it’s not what you say, it’s what you leave out. Suff* it to say, we all have a cho*. We can give in to coward* or fight for just*. 

*, *, baby.

"It’s your puzzle. Solve it any way you want.”

I read that quote in Deb's "How to Solve the New York Times Crossword" primer when I first attempted doing the puzzles, and it was truly liberating advice. Back then I was still struggling with Mondays. Instead of routinely abandoning puzzles because of an actress I didn't know or a currency I'd never heard of, it gave me permission to complete what I'd started, which helped me develop the skill to eventually solve without looking anything up. (Um, usually.) I'm sure I'd have given up crosswords long ago if I'd remained convinced that researching an answer was cheating. So, thanks for that. I'm grateful.

Anyway, I enjoyed this puzzle, for the theme, the cluing (e.g., [Make in the end]), and for the answers that still were real words with ICE removed. Thanks for the fun!

I did not 'get' the trick because neat whisky for me has no relation to ICE! 
Neat whisky in Scotland means without added water, lemonade, cola, ginger ale etc. You only do that with cheap whisky. Ice isn't usually used. Malt whisky - absolutely no ice, nothing. 

Otherwise, I very nice solve for me. Lots of helpful crossers and I only revealed the Windows clue.

I had no idea what a deli device could be, so I accepted SLR as correct. Same with DROLL - must be US slang, it does say idiomatically. OFF HOURS - why not? PRY? B N TO? More slang - for "be nice to"? More logical than some slang I've seen.

Enjoyable.

Deb, I’m with you on the I/O. 
Great puzzle!!! Enjoyed it immensely.

Weird rebus. Didn't work very well.

Easy puzzle after it was seen.

Average clueing and fill. 

5.5/10

Didn't we very recently have a puzzle that did something similar with ICE?  I remember it having a similar revealer.  Is this just a case of Déjà vu?  Was it a dream?

I expected to come to the comments and see posters say that we just had one like this a few weeks ago.  

I'm not complaining, just confused.
It's like a "Reverse-Rebus" Thursday! N(ICE)!
I NEEDED A NAP when I finished this puzzle, but did have fun with it even though I missed having a rebus

This reminded me of an old game show "You Don't Say." It had several iterations, but my favorite host was Tom Kennedy. Here's a link to one episode. He would end each show with the tag line "And remember, it's not what you say that counts; it's what you don't say." https://youtu.be/ozxUjQN598c
I love revisiting a puzzle, finding the one error that's mucking up an entire section for me, and then having everything fall into place. Kudos to Kareem for this puzzle.

A capital-P puzzle today.

Sunday, we had a puzzle where tiny scissors, on the line between two squares, represented the word ONCE.  For example, the scissors appeared between the C and R of the answer TO WHOM IT MAY CRN – you had to imagine the ONCE there.

Today’s Puzzle is a layer more difficult.  Yes, you have to imagine ICE in the answer, but there is nothing, like Sunday’s scissors, to tell you where it goes.  

That’s a marvelous riddle to crack!  The gimmick hit me with a delectable “Oho!”.  

The Puzzle battled me on another front – no-knows – of which I ran into more than a few.  They created barren white spaces that lingered until I cracked the ICE.

Along the way there was beauty: WEND, DROLL, ABSCOND, THRUMS.  And lovely touches by Kareem to have the ICE-less words still be actual words, to have the theme answers be symmetrical, and to have two revealers.

Potent and Pleasing, a worthy Thursday.  Thank you, Kareem!
So fun! 35 down was the finishing stroke for me and put a bow on the whole clever puzzle. I love hearing that the letters "ice" don't appear in sequence anywhere else in the grid... neat!
Easy

Whew. And Wow! Typical slow start for me and I was appropriately puzzled for quite a while. But then... finally catching on to the trick was just a great 'aha' moment and suddenly the puzzle became fairly easy to solve. Don't recall another one quite like this. Amazing. 

And... one very unusual puzzle find today. Of course I'll put that in a reply.

...

So for those of you who want to complain about Thursdays, I just finished the most diabolical, monstrous, Thursday I can recall. The date is Sept 16th 2016 Ian Livengood. Stop here if you don’t want a spoiler
.
.
.
The revealer was in three parts and was ANAGRAM THE FIRST WORD IN EACH CLUE. And that’s what you needed to do. Not just the Downs, or the Acrosses—but Every. Single. Clue. Of course you couldn’t solve the revealer without figuring the trick out first, so it was no use. There was no other hint to the trick except eventually noticing how squirrelly the clues were—I got it with “Manila alternative in a guessing game” (Animal—the answer was MINERAL). You’d think once you figured out the anagrams the clues at least were straightforward—but NO. Here’s some examples: “Trains (strain) for an NHL game”—OCANADA. “Reigns (singer) at a music hall” —BOCELLI.
Somehow I got through this one without figuring out every anagram. I shudder to imagine the comments (they didn’t save them that far back). But bottom line before I complain about a too tricky Thursday I will remember this one, and while I will respect everyone’s negative comments as always going forward,  outwardly inwardly I will be thinking “Quit your whining it can always be worse”. Nothing can get more ridiculous than this one.
FONRITPAQOMOH!  OMG, Deb, ICR!
Suff to say, a very sweet solve.
NEAT!
This is the first Thursday puzzle I've ever done where I didn't have to look up any of the clues!! (I did still check my answers as I went, but I'm making progress!)

Thank you to Mr Ayala for a lovely, chewy Thursday puzzle.  There were some delightful misdirects and clever clues today!  My favorite, which provoked a literal LOL, has to be 28D.  I reckon they could use some hugs these days.

Y’all have a lovely day and be kind where you can.

Saw the theme almost immediately and solved this in near record time ... except I didn't.

Had entered WIND rather than WEND for "Meander", and failed to notice that the author's name was then RIADE. 

So another (short) streak bites the dust.

Very nice puzzle that seemed suitable for either a Wednesday or a Thursday.

The two main theme clues were among my last ones in. So I had already put in answers through answering the crossers (and through NOTABLE being sorta conspicuous). I only worked out the no "ICE" thing after looking at my solved crossword. Still a decent time by my standards and my second Thursday in a row without any cheating.
And 46D also applies, homonymically.

Oohhh - and one more puzzle find. A Sunday from January 8, 1994 by Richard Silvestri with the title: "Piecework." Don't recall seeing another one quite like this. It's all in the clues. On the verge of dad jokes. Some theme clue and answer examples: "Ran into a doctor?" METAPHYSICIAN "Against lateral portions?" CONSIDERATIONS "Finance a mind reader?" FUNDAMENTALIST "Corroded by a fine spray?" MISTRUSTED "Indian river test?" INDUSTRIAL "Discourage blokes?" DETERGENTS And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=1/8/1984&g=84&d=A ...
I drink sparkling water without —
32A a little misleading. Released in 1999, performed at the SB halftime show and reentered the charts in 2022, but I do not consider Still Dre to be “of” 2022.

Very nice device, but one I never caught onto.
Duh, knew what NEAT meant, but never saw the missing “ice”.
Very clever.  My only solace - got Wordle and Connections.

Really great, this puzzle.  Unfortunately for me, I solved the entire puzzle without figuring out the gimmick.  Immediately after solving, however, I looked again at 48A and the aha moment arrived.  All the themers checked out, as I knew they would, 35D was a bonus aha moment.

In our early retirement years, we enjoy our hobbies and we travel quite extensively. I play my guitars regularly (always have) and I'm an avid fitness devotee (always have been).
Today's agenda:
 - Practice: self control
 - Exercise: restraint 
 - Travel: on the high road
 - Celebrate: others that do the same.
 😇

Pretty sure I'm not the first to think that this puzzle is "the Kareem of the crop!"  (I'll check for Mike's post later....)

I saw all the clues that are Unknowns (Neo/Matrix; Van Halen; really old novel;Tonkatsu; Windows malfunction; composer; philosopher; rap hit) and my heart sank a bit.  I got up at 6 a.m., walked for 45 minutes, and already I NEEDED A NAP!
How could a "risky endeavor" be DROLL?  
How could I forget "chiromancy?"
ETHNObotanist?
It was 24A that enabled the light to dawn.  
Wonderful puzzle!
Proper puzzling pleasure.  Some BENTO would be nICE right now.  Many thanks.
Going to have to get me a FONRITPAQOMOH t-shirt... Thank you for the chortle, Deb, and the really fun puzzle, Kareem!

Today’s puzzle was a 🤦🏻‍♀️
I filled the entire grid, then came here to see what the trick was b/c the starred clues (mostly filled with crosses) just did not make sense. The revealer was an easy one due to the Hozier song (which will now be a day long earworm) .

Ahh when the clouds parted … 🧊

Magnifnt construction, and fun too! 

The best adv for becoming proficient at Thursday trickery...
Pract, pract, pract.

As Dr. Sidney Freedman once said, “Ladies and gentlemen, take my adv. Pull down your pants and slide on the   “.
A quick, lively Thursday puzzle. I luckily caught onto the theme quickly, even without the revealer, and set a new personal Thursday best at a bit under 10 minutes. Thanks for the puzzle, Mr. Ayala.

This was great! Had my brows furrowed for the first 12 mins or so, trying frantically to understand a rebus that would fit BENICETO and OFFICEHOURS and SLICER. Such a fun theme and very very clever. Never heard of WEND before but now I do!

WEND and READE sure is a tricky little cross. 

Had to cheat to get that bad boy.
So fun! A fast solve, but checking the revealer and figuring out why some of those early words were coming out funny was very satisfying, and 28D clue got an audible laugh from me, too!

Solid Thursday! Very crunchy fill. 

I will slightly knock FOMO since the clue should have been abbreviated as welll *per the rules, right editors?* 

But the brilliance of the TSA clue was the big takeaway for me!

cute!

i didn’t figure out the clever construct until i was just about finished ~ otherwise, i found this only slightly crunchy ~ a fast and easy solve for me today

no ice, i agree!

happy thursday, everyone!

I. LOVE. THIS. PUZZLE.

I hereby nominate it for PUZZLE OF THE YEAR.

Thank you, Kareem Ayas, for a sparkling, interesting, thought-provoking, lively, wonderful puzzle!

Dear Kareem, you had me at ABSCOND. Such a great word, and very Downton Abbey-esque, evoking one of those knavish footmen, who, having gotten a parlour maid in the family way, ABSCONDed with the earl's silver snuffboxes. The foul varlet! Cross that with a Van Halen song, and I was a fan of this puzzle, literally from square one. (My love is rotten to the core.)

As for the theme, I knew something was up with BENTO. Sure, it's packed "with kindness," but it's a meal, not a "treat." OFF(ICE) HOURS sealed it for me.

And hopefully, everyone who eschews video games remembered yesterday's BOSS LEVEL for 5D.
Once again, I got it without cheating, but I still don't get it.

OMG…I stared in frustration at the solved puzzle for about 10 minutes before it hit me like a ton of bricks (or ice)!  It made no sense, until it did, which of course made me smile!  Great fun for a Thursday morning!
Very fun puzzle, took me a good while to figure out the theme but once I got there, the fill was nice and smooth, just like a premium bourbon that doesn't need any ice.
I'm slipping. Got all the entries, still couldn't figure out the theme.

Excellent puzzle!  Even with the revealer clue entered I didn't truly "get" the theme until I finally got to SLR.  (I was misdirected and stumbling over the letters n, e, a, and t being present in the first theme answer, and a possible stone/rock theme, among other delays.)  What a neat little trick, and so well executed.

And that clue for the far overused TSA - wow, just terrific.  Worthy of the spit-take and more.  How in the world was that previously edited out?  Unimaginable.

I didn't even notice/get the rocks-out connection until I went back to review just now.  What a fine piece of work.
Solved the whole puzzle only to get stuck at bEND/bELLOK. Wondered why that phrase hasn't rung a bell.

Love this puzzle! Thankfully, I was not drinking my iced tea as I puzzled.  No spit take though I did snort loudly when I got it. Having just listed to The Daily from 10/10, where I first learned of Will  Shortz and Will Wang’s thoughts on cheating, I loved seeing this again. I do enjoy learning new things from the crossword! I had to go remind myself of Ain’t Talking ‘bout Love and have been enjoying 80s hair band music this morning.

Please, more from Kareem Ayas!

Re: looking up answers 
Back in olden days when there was no internet and we looked forward to wading through the Sunday Times till we got the Magazine section. We shared the puzzle back and forth, and we also had no less than 4 puzzle dictionaries, a thesaurus and a regular dictionary. I considered it learning things I did not know. Call it whatever you like and play your game your way. I am glad Will Shortz and predecessor agree!
Who drinks iced Earl Grey??
So fun to figure out the theme midway and use that to fill. Enjoyed this!

I really enjoyed this puzzle. I especially loved all the clueing. I too loved the 28D clue that Deb mentioned. Hee.

As usual for Thursday-and-on puzzles, I went back-'n-forth with some clues, considering two alternative meanings of a word (like 'bug') until the crosses led me to a THIRD meaning of the word I hadn't thought of! I thought entomology or espionage, did NOT think "I.T.". Excellent. N(ice) epiphanies throughout.

I caught on to the trick sometime in the middle of the solve, I forget at which clue, so in my mind I then included/added "ICE" to the asterisked clues and it really helped.

So overall, I thought this puzzle was a good'n to make one stirred but not shaken. Kareem crafted it wittily soda solvers can have a good time. Lots of droll, rye clues. Plenty of good, fun misleads, but with enough doable entries and crosses to scotch any overly wayward detours. A gin-uine delight. Smooth, challenging, chewy but not rocky. I bet even The Famous Grouse 'Eva H' might like this one. (OK maybe not). But it certainly might make your average Jim beam.

Oh, and BTW let's please stop calling him 'Kareem'. He's the *CO-PILOT*!! ("Airplane!" reference) (but surely you caught that)

O frabjous day! Kahlua callay! N🧊 puzzle.
🍸🥃 🚫🧊🧊🧊🚫 🥃🍸

I didn’t manage to solve this without helps, but greatly enjoyed this one. No ice! How timely! Oh, that we could treat people with the dignity and respect they are afforded for being made in the image of God!

Brutal solve, thought I was going to have to do a lookup when the last area filled in (still better than yesterdays slop).

Tough but fair. Clever theme.

I'll join the chorus: this puzzle was delightful. I knew that something was afoot immediately, the instant I got to 5A, and had fun with a series of guesses about that until I hit 5A the second time. Then all the theme answers fell at once. A nice little clatter of ice.

Deb, are you working remotely from a sunny Southern clime? Just asking.

This puzzle reminded me of my trip to India ten years ago. You were not supposed to use ice in your drinks because there was no guarantee it was made with safe water, so I learned to drink whiskey with just a couple drops of (bottled) water to take the edge off. Still drink it that way! Tough puzzling today but managed to work through it and the streak lives on!

Very enjoyable Thursday puzzle today. It took a good while before I saw what the theme was, then a pleasant time going back and making it happen all over the puzzle. (I especially liked APPENDiceS.) The upper left area was tough since I didn't see SET IN STONE for a long time. I do not think "Brute" is a good clue for BOOR. (A brute is insensitive while a boor just has bad manners.)

I posted a link to Van Halen performing Ain’t Talkin’ ‘Bout Love at the US Festival in my original post last night, but an even more apropos ear worm for today is Hozier’s Too Sweet 🥃 https://youtu.be/NTpbbQUBbuo?si=IfHnYYs6rHvQMCti Enjoy!

Hmm.. I put in the ice as rebuses and it wouldn’t take it that way.

Liked the puzzle a lot but typically  either a rebus or just the first letter would work in the solution

That was NEAT. Cottoned on fairly quickly but had a hiccup at the end when I thought I’d completed it but the clock kept ticking. My error was WIND for WEND. Riade was an unlikely name for my unknown author.
Even though it took me a little longer than usual, I really loved this theme - here's to No ICE!  Thank you, Kareem, for such a brilliant theme - I hope we see more from you!
Big fan of Kareem's puzzles and this was another great one.

I was feeling a little salty over the WEND/READE crossing (as surely there’s Charles RiADE somewhere…), but then I heard what I’d been saying in my head, over and over, for the past 20 minutes. 

Let’s all say it together:

No ICE
No ICE
No ICE
No ICE
No ICE

A DROLL puzzle with NOTABLE timeliness. I am grateful for those themers, and for all the ways we can remove ICE from our grid.
Sure there wasn’t a political motivation behind this theme??
Can I say, this was a NEAT puzzle?
Sorry, but droll is NOT risky behavior...

Generally the word "certain" in a crossword puzzle clue implies that the answer is a specific example of the given category. Today, however, we have [Certain Windows hard drive malfunction] solving to I/O ERROR, an extremely generic term for a wide variety of issues involving communication between the CPU and other computer components. When a computer displays this message, it's basically admitting that it has no idea what went wrong. So, yeah, it took me a while to figure that one out.

A well constructed puzzle that would have been a LOT more enjoyable if the theme wasn't implied so obtusely.  I solved it like a normal crossword, looked at the highlighted entries and thought "Well, I could sit here trying to figure out HOW all this connects but I've already solved the puzzle so what's the point?"

I enjoyed the theme today.  I initially thought it was a Rebus when I saw OFFICE HOURS clearly not fit, great lightbulb moment when you figure out what NEAT means.

One Natick for me, the crossing of IVES and AVER.  I've never heard the word 'Aver' nor of 'Ives', and the fact that SLICER was the only theme clue where the word didn't spell another actual word or phrase when you take the ICE out made me doubting what otherwise seemed like an easy answer.

a timely, clever, and fun thursday. i only started solving crosswords 2ish months ago, and this is the closest i'm come to completing a thursday with minimal square reveals. and the theme...chef's kiss

I enjoyed this puzzle a lot.

Though it took me a while to figure out that there was no place in it for chicken massala.
Can someone explain to me how Still D.R.E. is a 2022 hit? That song came out in 2001?

Wow first time in a long while that I found Thursday easier than Wednesday! I wish I could still drink whiskey NEAT. My esophagus won’t take it anymore, so I have to add lots of ICE to water it down. This puzzle could have easily been political which I would have welcomed. I expect that this Saturday lots of people will be shouting “NO ICE” in the streets!
A possible title for today's puzzle: De (ICE)ification.

I am registering my strenuous disapproval and disappointment at the removal of the top comment, Steve L’s “if only” comment about ICE. It was anodyne. It didn’t reference any news story. There are other comments still up with the same message. 

Don’t be such snowflakes about ice, Times!
I loved this!

Reposted:

In which ICE disappears.

If only...

Fun!! Cute!! Interesting that two puzzles this week required dropping letters completely... I can feel my brain working hard to think outside the puzzle letter boxes (or inside?) and will be on the lookout for this in the future.

Appreciate that the words with missing letters are still words! 

Fill was pretty easy, a little bit of a break after yesterday's toughie.
Easy theme (for a whiskey drinker), but tricky puzzle! WEND/READE and EMU/FAUN were nightmarish crosses. Thanks for the puzzle Mr. Ayas
Given today's political climate, I was happy to have a sanctuary puzzle with no ICE in it. The oreos and emus did get in. The triple trickery was fun. It was tough but I did enjoy myself.
No ice is neat, huh? On the surface, it's bartender lingo, but could it also be a comment on the nation's current immigration policies?

Quality puzzle, just one minor issue for me. Noticeably and Noticeable both work for that rebus answer and if you don't know the pop culture reference to Dre, you'll be stuck on Dry for a while with a seemingly valid entry. Yes, yes, pop culture references are part of the fun and the turmoil, but seemed a better "Dre" clue could have been issued that an obscure reference when there are many more on offer. Not the best cluing imho.

Not a fan of the use of phrases as answers in general, but this puzzle was taking liberties. It just screams “poor vocabulary” to me. Too many multi-word answers and pop culture references. Not hard, just not my cup of tea 😘

To anyone who tried to make this a rebus puzzle:  how did you decide which square to include the ICE letters?  Looks like you would have a choice to make.  For example, for 3D, to turn NOTABLE into NOTiceABLE, you could either add "ice" to the third square, to create "Tice" in that square, or you could put the "ice" in the fourth square to create "iceA".  AFAIK, in all past rebuses, the extra letters always belong in one, and only one, square.
Neat trick! Enjoyed this one. Got stuck thinking it was office tours for some reason for ages but eventually figured it and maintained my streak
I absolutely loved this puzzle!! A perfect Thursday challenge.

One of my best friends, Tom, was a preeminent expert on the music of Charles Ives. He passed away in April of 2024. I miss him. In case you're not familiar with Ives' music, here is a youtube of "Central Park in the Dark," (1906), in which someone has made a rather nice "music video" to the recording of it by Michael Tilson Thomas and the SFO, which is one of the best. It's about 7 minutes long, and very pretty. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bx25XRrzjRo&list=RDBx25XRrzjRo&start_radio=1
Kareem, hope you serve up anotherr neat puzzle soon!

Sitting on the deck of our ship, after leaving the Virgin Islands, and as my husband snoozes, I'm contemplating how fast the ICE in my rum and diet has disappeared. If only life imitated art, I mean, if you consider a rum and diet coke on the deck of the ship art, which I do. 

And this really was a very fun puzzle!! But I looked back at it again today I got a whole another kick out of it!! That's always a good puzzle!

I think I'm ready to start changing my puzzle-solving style.  I've been doing the puzzle for several decades (since 1960, when I moved to NYC), and I've made a few changes.  So have the powers that be at the NYT puzzle desk.

What I mostly have to change, I think, is looking up things that I don't know and have to possible way of figuring out:  things like pop music and stars, recent flicks and stars, catch phrases from those movies, catch phrases used by whatever-letter generation is being cited.   Stuff like that.

Just accept that I am a lot older now, and not interested in being particularly in tune with current culture.  And that's okay.  If I get used to it.  I'll keep reminding myselfthat it's my puzzle.

But I did love the no ICE stuff.  These games/tricks/whatever you call them, are to me the best part of doing XWPs.  (Also, they don't require a lot of walking.)

Anyway, back to battling my landlord and cuddling my cat.

Thanks all involved for a fun solve.
“Still Dre” was a 1999 rap hit, from the album 2001. How did you come up with 2022?
Re columnist Deb's "fear of not relaxing in the peace and quiet of my own home, or FONRITPAQOMOH" - I too have this. An alternative acronym for it is JOMO, or Joy Of Missing Out. :-)
i got the whole puzzle right, but i didn't enter the inserted blocks of letters the way you wanted, so you refused to recognize this. this happens to me all the time.

Very N. But in at least one novel I've read with mentions of single malt scotch, one was supposed to add just a LITTLE water (from a pure mountain burn if available of course). 
  Anyone? I like the stuff neat myself but it can be harsh.

I loved this puzzle so much. Thank you for the humor and the challenge, Kareem Ayas. I will definitely keep an eye out for more of yours. 

It took me longer than it probably should have to see what the trick was. I KNOW I really should read ALL the clues before starting to fill things in, and if I had done that today I would have seen the clever trick much sooner. But I stumbled happily around, thinking it was pretty tough, but finding places I could fill in. I went for my 4 mile walk, up hill and down, listening to my audiobook (“The Winners” by Fredrik Packman—SO good and I highly recommend it). I came home had my lunch and tackled this amazing puzzle again and finally saw the light! Or the absence of ICE! 😊
Thanks to the whole team 👏🏻
That's it. I'm out.
Fairly vanilla puzzle that would make Mr. Van Winkle proud. Gonna go pour out a celebratory dram of scotch now.

I absolutely loved this puzzle, and finished over 5 minutes faster than usual. What a treat!

10D provided my "aha" moment fairly early in the solve, and the rest was smooth as, er, ice!

Count me as a fan - it was an incomprehensible jumble until it wasn’t - which is typical for Thursday.  The (ice?) blocks finally fell into place after I had more than half the puzzle filled in.  Then the whole neat/rocks out bits made sense.  And, hey - the ice-less entries are all words on their own - no small feat.  Good stuff.
That was pretty NEAT. And I'm also a fan of getting rid of ICE.

Great puzzle and a lot of fun, though it took me a lot longer than it should have to realize it wasn't a rebus. I recognized that "ice" was missing pretty early on, but it took reading Deb's column (and a gigantic forehead slap) to realize I just needed to omit the letters. Once I sorted that out, the rest fell into place pretty quickly.

Looking forward to more like this from Mr. Ayas!
Nice puzzle. Took me a bit longer to crack it than it should have, because I got NOTABLE early and it seemed like a reasonable solution for “Conspicuous”…. But eventually all fell into place.
I'll have to check my receipt, but I distinctly remember ordering my country neat!

Wow, in what might be a first, my solve was a full 2 minutes faster than the XWStats Median Solve Time

Nice recovery after being bested by a Wednesday

Nooo not another missing-letters puzzle. But the new words formed are actually words, so, kudos! Lots of stale chestnuts though: OREO, EMU, TSA. But the clues are witty and actually funny, so kudos again. 

I think that's the first time I've ever seen HEGEL in an NYT puzzle! IVES was also nice, great neglected composer.
61A I had NEAT but when I realized the theme clues were missing ICE, I changed it to WITH, as in WITH (ICE). I was quite fond of that! Too bad it destroyed my SW corner.

Great construction work by Kareem! I love when Thursday theme entries like these result in other real word/phrases. Very clever to put NOTABLE in the NW corner, it fits the clue with or without ICE. Took me a few more clues to realize what was going on.
AVER/AVow has become a KEA/LOA for me.
loved the tsa clue “greet with open arms”!

@david dell no rebus in this one. If whiskey is served neat, it means there's no ice. So for the theme answers, "ice" is removed.

@david dell. 
1) any rebus entry needs to work in both across and down entries. (This might involve the use of a / to show different values for each direction, or some other device)
2) the revealer(s): NEAT meaning “no ice” and ROCKSOUT which can be read with the same meaning, both indicate that “ice” is to be omitted.

@Teresa To be clear, I fully got the theme! I’m just often surprised to see commenters complain that a rebus wasn’t accepted, in situations where a rebus option makes no sense to me.

@Stephen

I'm sort of a newbie. I've been doing puzzles for about two months. I had done some puzzles when I was younger but not for years and years.

Now, I think you need to add the rebus to this puzzle. But the rebus works only one way--only across or down--but may have TWO meanings. 

Let's look at 48A. Deli device. You add some ICE and you have a SLICER! SLR is a nice thing and a common answer in puzzles--a Single Lens Reflex camera, right?--but is it a Deli device? BENTO (5A) is nice. It certainly is a Treat with Kindness. (My mom made me salads with half pineapple slices for smiles.) But BENICETO is also a great way to Treat with kindness. PRY (24A) is a nice word but PRICEY so much more means Expensive. Talk one-on-one to the professor. Love to. Great in OFFHOURS (10D) but maybe better in OFFICEHOURS. (It depends on the prof, maybe.) DROLL (62A) is a lovely word. But I much prefer DICEROLL for a Risky endeavor (62A).

You can read everything twICE.

My experience was much the same--go as far as you can go, then give yourself permission to use Google or use Reveal or anything else you need to do.

@Peter C.

Like you, I looked things up so that one day I would no longer need to cheat.  But folks do these puzzles for recreation so they can call it whatever they want.

@Peter C.

Funny, my experience was kinda the opposite of yours. I started out solving puzzles casually (cheating here and there as needed), and anytime I’d come across a really challenging one and eventually hit a wall, I can distinctly remember feeing outraged when I’d finally cave and hit the “reveal grid” button — specifically, I remember exclaiming to myself, “it’s not even that those entries are hard, they just don’t make sense!!!”

At some point, it occurred to me to stop cheating unless I was reeeally stumped. And what do you know: turns out all those clues in the harder puzzles actually *did* make plenty of sense all along, and I just wasn’t good enough at solving to grok them!

All that to say, I think that developing crossword solving skills does require being prepared to cheat (rather than walking away from a puzzle)…but if you want to improve quickly, you’ve gotta be willing to torture yourself a fair bit before doing so.

@Peter C.

I’ve never thought that looking up an answer is cheating. I think of it as learning. 🙂

@Rich in Atlanta As promised - a Sunday from May 12, 2013 by David J. Kahn with the title: "Simply Put." Never seen another one like this. First theme clue and answer: "With 44-, 63-, 77- and 93-Across, a long-winded piece of advice" POTENTIALCONSEQUENCES And then those other referenced answers: 44a: OFAPLANORDECISIONONE 63a: CANNOTREVERSESHOULDBE 77a: HEEDEDPRIORTOTHETIME 93a: ANACTIONISEFFECTUATED And then... down the middle of the puzzle: 24d: "This puzzle's long-winded advice, simply put" LOOKBEFOREYOULEAP Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/12/2013&g=24&d=D ....

@Rich in Atlanta Oh - and one more puzzle find. A Sunday from January 3, 1999 by Randolph Ross with the title: "Proverbial conflicts." Some theme clue and answer examples: "An eye for an eye, but also..." TURNTHEOTHERCHEEK "Good things come in small packages, but also..." THEBIGGERTHEBETTER "Two's company, three's a crowd, but also..." THEMORETHEMERRIER "Don't judge a book by its cover, but also..." CLOTHESMAKETHEMAN "Do unto others as you would have others do unto you, but also..." NICEGUYSFINISHLAST "He who hesitates is lost, but also..." LOOKBEFOREYOULEAP Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/3/1999&g=119&d=A ....

@Rich in Atlanta Once you realize that every NYC crossword has a trick, then part of the fun is figuring out what the trick it. When I first started doing these years ago, I would find out that there was a trick and get annoyed. Now I love the tricks.
And if you folks think there are too many tricks in these puzzles, here's something that happened to me with a puzzle from another publication. These puzzles generally didn't come with tricks. So there I was and all the across entries were very straightforward and easy BUT they did not match with the down entries, which SEEMED equally easy. I was so frustrated. Back in the day we did these in the newspapers, so I had to wait till the next day for the solution. So the next day comes and I look at the answer puzzle and I swear, I thought my brain took a hike. NOTHING made sense. Slowly, ever so slowly it began to dawn on me--all the answers were BACKWARD. Sure enough the date for that puzzle was APRIL 1st! TRUE STORY; that was the craziest puzzle I ever did.

The Archive shows that I solved that one, but of course, it having been nine years ago, I have no memory of the solve.  But I got a gold star, so I must have figured it out.

It seems to me that the key to solving it was to find the three "traps" of the revealer, and to realize that sometimes, crosswords have marquee answers in "parts," not "traps."  Seeing that probably was what unlocked the trick for me.  (Of course, I'm just guessing here.)

I'm not great at spotting anagrams, so I might just have worked the short ones until the rest of the other clues gave me enough information to deduce the answers.

The puzzle did take me a bit longer than twice my normal Thursday solve time.

@SP

Okay, it's done, but that was the least enjoyable puzzle I ever completed.  I had an advantage in figuring out the trick because I once worked with a client who was obsessed with 1 A, and she talked about it incessantly. 

The long torment of implementing said theme was not something I would want to endure again.  I only continued to prove to myself that I could do it.

I don't remember ever having such a negative feeling about a puzzle before.  Usually, I find reasons to like them, but this was just not for me.

Typically to find the error, I have to track down any answer that I don't know, and see if I can get a clue from the cross of what the questionable letter or letters should be. @Deadline
My sentiments exactly—except I do love going for walks and am thankful I can still do it. I too am old (it’s all relative) and I don’t take mobility for granted at all. One day at a time. 
I agree about looking things up when solving, which is fine by me when it’s needed—same categories as yours, rap song titles and so on. 
Today’s puzzle was a challenge for me but so much fun too.

@Deadline, I'm about two decades behind you in solving, but have also made similar adjustments to my solving parameters. Much of pop culture eludes me these days unless I hear it from my third grade students or younger colleagues. When I'm well and truly stumped, I look at the Wordplay column, but I find that most of the "tricky" clues aren't the ones I need help with! Then I don't hesitate to go to Google for a boost. Oftentimes, looking up one strategically placed clue, especially if it's a long one, gives me enough to power on through.

Happy solving!
